content:
er 8, 2014
 Everything I want, Nothing I don't  Kingdom Wars is a melting pot of different styles of games and game elements/mechanics. I personally view it as a Stronghold Crusaders + a dash of Total War + World of Warcraft (the RTS, not the MMO) + A strong influence of the game elements/mechanics of those web browser based games where you build a base and army and attack other people, get attacked etc. etc. I'm sure someone will correct me on the abreviation for that kind of game but I cant remember right now. Now here are some  VERY IMPORTANT  distinctions from the rest of those games that I and many people have been asking and looking for but have never found with other games similar to this one. The developers built into the game features that actually prevent a P2W environment!  For example there is absolutely no 'Low Energy! Come back tomorrow... OR pay us $5-$10-$20-$50(best BS deal!) to keep playing!' because  there is no energy.  You cannot be attacked or attack players of higher or lower level (premium units? stronger opponents!) and  you cannot be attacked while offline!   Finally, thank you!  Waiting for resources to gather and/or something to finish building and feel like there's nothing more to do in town? Make an army and go fight NPC/AI on the world map for gold and then use your spoils of war to buy those resources or even new units! Oh did i mention this is a great way to level up your units at the same time? Or just log off and go live your life and come back to find the resources collected while you were offline! Yes there is 'premium' currency  but  it is  reasonably and realisticly  obtainable in-game for your time + effort for free! Quest's and NPC/AI battle's being the best way I've found persoanlly. An actually entertaining story line. A suprisingly indepth and well made system for selecting your race, skills, and city location(s).  Single player  modes including campaign, seige, and seige defence.  You do have to pay $2 to unlock each of these modes however.  Personally this is not an issue for me as I don't plan on using single player mode, however it could be very useful to try out different seige strategies and really $2-$6 for this game is a ridiculously good deal considering some of the alpha games on here that cost $15 in the  hope  that they turn out good. Predetermined building locations make your city(s) astheticly pleasing, strategically challenging and easy to build! None of that layers and layers of wall's shinanigans like every one of those crappy web-based Base Building RTSMMO's Wow those first five elements are  exactly what people have been asking for in games similar to this for years.  That is a  huge  reason I like this game. Now I can feel satisfied that I finally found a good game out there where the developers/owner(s)/publisher actually give a **** about what me, the player, wants in a game rather than how much money is on the paycheck. From the bottom of my heart,  thank you  and I hope you cotinue building the game like this while keeping the same ideals! You know what's even better? If you actually do spend money on the game, lets say you buy a dragon for your army,  they protect your investment.  While your normal units disappear forever when they die, your premium units, like the dragon you bought, only get knocked out and lose a few levels. Oh and you can't make an army of just dragons because that would be P2W plus they can still be countered and defeated by a prepared player, there's a dragon slayer i got for  free  after all. Right off the bat they are giving me a unit that counters one of the stronger units in the game! To make it even more balanced there's a unit cap, each unit takes up a certain amount of space, so you have to choose what you bring to battle wisely, a small but individually strong group of heavy hitters? Perhaps a massive amount of inexpensive foot soldiers with archers? It's all about the strategy, not who had the larger wallet. Also you wanna know something awesome the premium days you can buy in this game? You choose which days you want to use them for. How many games can you think of that actually do that for their players? Personally i don't know a single one, because money. Now for the other side of the coin, this game has flaws as all games natuarlly do. Animations are decent, but not great. Yes things still take time to build but it's not ridiculous amounts (i.e. 5-7 days). You have to pay for extra cities (gotta make money somehow so this is perfectly reasonable and fine with me). The controls can't be customized and are a bit clunky, biggest issue for me personally is the right mouse button. It controls your units  but  it also moves the camera if you have a single unit selected, very annoying esspecially when your trying to moe just your hero. plus there's is a very noticeable delay between the click and the effect (at least for me on my laptop). Then sometimes nothing happens at all. Trying to organize and manage your units is awkward and needs to be streamed lined. Especially when you have to do it quickly (Very Frustrating). Not to mention you have to indiviually select units to activate their abilites/magic/skills/powers which is very hard when they are in combat. Theres also some minor graphical errors, especially when the weather changes and in a couple of cut scene's where the character(s) slowly turns invisible and OHMYGODTHEIREYESANDMOUTH! Personally I find that last type of glitch hilarious as it's actually pretty common in a lot of games. Upgrades and improvements of any and all kind require 'premium' currency, walls for example require an especially large ammount and you have 4 different one's to build, but like i said about premium currency, it is obtainable in-game for a reasonable amout of time and effort so a somewhat moot point. Still I love this game and plan on continuing to play it for quite some time at a casual level, kill some time here and there, build this and that, do a quest here and there. This is a game that easily works with how you play games, hard-core, casual, it dosen't matter because it caters to any type of play style. I have only been playing for 9.3 hrs at the time of this writing but i can already feel that within 30-45 days, I will have an impressive city and army to boot and will be knocking down a few peoples walls! I absolutely, highly recommend this game for people looking for a RTSMMO with RPG elements that lets you play at your own pace, your own schedule, your own style, your own budget and actually rewards you if you dont want to play all-day-everyday and throw money at it. Even if you do throw money at it it still goes  far beyond  what any other game I have played or known will do for you for your investment. See you on the battle field and if you attack me, you shall feel the power and dismay of my elven arrows and Magical superiority!This review helpful in anyway? Let me know below by leaving a comment and/or give a thumbs up and/or down.

content:
er 2, 2014
												I would like to start off by saying that I am a big RTS\RPG fan.  I am also a big fan of MMO games.  I have played this game with an open mind, as I suggest anyone else who tries this game, do without having any pre-conceived ideas or expectations.  The game mechanics are very user-friendly and easy to become accostumed to.  I have read many comments regarding the graphics.  Being an older gamer (over 40) I found myself getting a little nostalgic, which I really liked.  The game is excellent.  The concept is great.  The experience is one of the best I have had.  The most appealing aspect of this game, in my opinion, is that it is Free-To-Play.  Keep in mind that it is a RTS game and it will take time to do all the great stuff there is to do in this game.  So without further ado, good luck building your Kingdom and forging your Empire!

content:
er 3, 2014
												Now color me surprised when i find out there is a FTP MMO RTS that does not take after facebooks track history of special in-game currency that only money provides, color me when more suprised when it turns out to be a game remarkably simular to my childhood favorite Age of Empires.Kingdom Wars is a MMO base builder Real time stratagy game that takes after Age of empires. It takes you into a wonderfully colorfull and well groomed fantasy land that is gorgouse to look at the more you adventure. Aside from Peasents and their endless offers of potato's you'll find a colorfull collection of unit types and specials that all races can use.Thats right. you can be a human race, and have elven archers with orc brutes as your spearhead force. Whats more cool then that?Oh right DRAGONS!!! You Can Have Dragons at your beck and call!!Kingdom Wars brings to life THE entire fantasy adventure, dwarfs, elves, giant treeents, rampaging warg packs, ogres minotaurs and more await you in this well packed game. And its all Free to play. Additionally you can enjoy the entire game without having to spend money into it. Not that the fancy customization options wont tempt you.As this is still a growing game, there are to be expected issues here and there, but with a lively staff, and friendly active in-game moderators anything that does happen can be worked out and solved so you can return to rasing your kingdom and adventuring across the world.

er 2, 2014
												Having grown up with the Stronghold series, this is a must try for anyone following in similar footsteps.There are several features that I love from Kingdom Wars that gives it that little boost:Firstly Resources are gathered when you are both on and offline which help greatly, especially when you are trying to raise funds to buy crowns.Decent F2P Model. While there are always the Cape-Crusaders who will nitpick at every F2P and say how P2W it is, even though they aren’t, KWs is a Play to Win as opposed to Pay to Win. While there are of course boosts and the ‘premium’ currency, all of this is earned in game and is rather pay for convenience.And one of the best things I have seen on here is the fantastic moderator team they have in game. There never seems to be a question too trivial for them and they are willing to go to the ends of the earth to help you or give you direct link with someone who can.

content:
er 9, 2014
												Kingdom Wars is a great game if you like city building and rts games. I have spent over 100 hours playing and love it.  The game does have bugs and crashes once in a while though.  You can use ingame money to buy pvp protection if you do not like pvp.  You may notice that the game has a cash shop and think that the things the packages gives are overpowered like 100k gold and 5 minotaurs and so on.  That amount of gold is easy to get after a day of playing and minotaurs are only good if you know how to use them.  The game is not pay to win in any way since the amount of bundles you can purchase is limited and everything you get from the bundles can be killed or looted.  I have personally destroyed people with bundle troops with some of the weakest troops in the game because they did not know how to use them.Overall a great game that I recommend.

content:
er 2, 2014
												Not a free to play - This is not a free to play game, and it is easy to see that it is not. Most games that are MMO city builders like this rely heavily on users buying boosters. This games does not. First of all, there are only three boosters in the game, and you can not use more than 1 of them per in-game account/city. The boosters that are there give you resources that are helpful to a beginner, but if you build your city up a bit, they can easily be aquired.PvP - When I first started, I was afraid of going into the PvP part of the game. I was afraid that people who have already made giant cities and huge armies could walk in and take all of my things; this is definitely not the case. They have balanced the game enough so that you can only fight people within 10% of your army strength. 10% is so little, that it makes you rely only on good tactics. It makes EVERY siege/co-op/defence really fun and actually a really good match. Also, most of the online playing is co-op, which is honestly one of the most fun parts of the game. You can raid AI cities or do quests with your friends, and it makes the gameplay really fun, without getting completely screwed over. Also, if you REALLY do not like PvP, you can buy the single player campaign for only $1.99, which is honestly a good deal for how fun this game is.Building your city - It is hard to build your city at the start, since resources are scarce. This is the point where the co-op takes place and is a big help. You can do quests with your friends and fight armies, and take all of the resources off of their cold dead bodies. This part beats every other city builder into dust. You can actually command your armies, instead of it being auto resolved for you. The game features 3 different races: humans, elves, and orcs. Each race is very balanced, and it would be a very hard decision on if you were to ask which race was the best. This lets you face other online players (or play WITH them) without worrying that their units are SOO much better than yours.Raiding cities - Later on, once you have a big and tough army, you can start raiding AI cities. There are 30 (from my knowledge) cities that you can siege and either loot or make your vassel. Looting can be helpful, and gives you a lot of resources; while vassels give you resources over time.Do not be turned away because it is an online city builder. Most of this game is co-op, instead of facing other players. You can join a clan and help each other out by sending each other resources. My in-game name is Enki, for anyone who has any more questions or wants to raid some AI with me! :)

content:
ry 1, 2015
												This game has been a roller coaster. I first bought it on GameStop because of the promise of a single player mode which did eventually happen. I noticed MAJOR performance hits on Steam and Reverie's developers suggested using their OWN client which users reported provided a MUCH better experience in terms of performance. THEN Reverie discontinued their own client, and even on this I7 rig I have, this game lags and stutters while games like Supreme Commander and Supreme Commander 2 - develpped around the same time and with MUCH larger worlds and literally thousands of units runs beautifully. This game has has a troubled history and a visit to the HeavenGames forum for this game will reveal that history.The single player risk like portion of the game has been removed. This is strictly a PvP type game. If that's your thing, then you will like this game. I prefer single player and coop PvE. All of that said, I really hate writing this somewhat negative review as Reverie seem to be a stidio that really wants to make this game something special. The problem however - and you'll note other users have expressed the same concern in the Hub for this game - is that Reverie keeps releasing mega-patches but fails to address core game issues. When, as a company, ypou get rid of something that improves performance while simiultaneously releasing more and "bigger" stuff is really taking one step forward and two steps back. If you'll pardon the trope, this COULD have been the RTS fantasy strategy game to rule them all. It isn't unfortunately so it's back to playing Medieval Total War from the physical discs for me. I am sorry Reverie, you tried but you lack focus.

content:
r 27, 2014
												Feels a lil glued up in the unit tasking, but other than that looks good in my mind and instantly had a lil bit of a Black and White feel to it. I like that units are in platoons, but a more Total war approach with unit orders in battle would be nice. I give it a personal 8/10Edit 1:So now that Ive gotten some more time in the game, I must say Ive been gladly surprised with Kingdom Wars. However, as with any game, there are problems, and Ill try my best to be the most helpful I can to new players and to the devs in ideas I have. 1. units orders: The manner in which units are ordered around the battlefield is good to a point, but seriously sucks in combat. Basically, if you arn't used to normal RTS games and using those command groups, then be prepared to be annoyed. The forming of solid lines of defense/attack are simple to the point of insanity. You either just run everything up at once, save for cavalry and archers, and hope you win or you take too long to form proper lines and risk taking huge damaged from enemy archer or crossbowmen in the process. The way to fix this in my mind would be to rip the current system and add in a more Total war type of battle system, making for a more fluid experience (Or just add in the ability to lock different formations to a hotkey, Idk)2. The economy: This games economy surprised me for the better in some areas, but I found lack luster in others. The dominate reliance on wood is good, but the ability to build houses out of stone instead of wood would make for the bigger projects and upgrades coming faster, and make the city look better if they had the textures to match. The crown system is amazing, being a resource that you gain from gold instead of a bought currency for real money, and making it essential to manage your crown total very carefully so not to leave you without that one vital upgrade. The food resource in this game also makes for fun play in that there are not just farms but also animals to use to produce and it just adds a much greater sense of life to your city.3. The combat: The full on combat of this game is the biggest complaint I have. It seems that the battles try to simulate tactics, but in the end it seems all that is needed is to have a direct line to enemy units and just be a Russian as possible (Quantity wins) I would recommend changing it up to make it so certain units like the crossbowmen would do so much damage that it basicallly one hits units. Another this is the special units. Through the quests I recieved a Dragonslayer, which in my mind, would be fairly good agaisnt Dragons. But when I sent him agianst the Dragon that spawned as part of the quest, well, lets just say the rest of my army was quickly heading that way. I believe that some of the special units should be very, very good against what they are meant to go against.This is my current review, as I discover more of the game and figure it out for myself, Ill let every one know what I think, still a 8/10.A video review will be uploaded within the next day or two, will post link with this written one.

content:
er 2, 2014
												This game holds you from beginning to end. Unlike the vast majority of games this is not "pay to win", there are Easy methods to get all features. There are some bugs and problems that may trouble at first, but the game has a group of excellent mods ready to help him in-game chat. And if any be present, the vast majority of players tends to help newcomers. The game also has a PVP system that only allows troops are clashing with similar powers, thereby making any veteran can come and crush you. Apart from that you can easily avoid all the battles that do not want to face, just by paying small amounts of resources. Every battle even if you surrender, given protection against attacks that can be easily canceled. The only important feature of the game "Crowns" can be earned in various ways (pvp, pve, coop) plus conversion of "gold" in "Crowns" and those who have money it is possible to buy. It is also possible to join in alliances, which allow the construction of a "guild hall" which allows further increase its combat capability and obtaining resources to increase the amount of armies you can pussuir. Several special units like Dragons and Minotaurs. Curing units, siege units and many others. If you like games like age of empires online and would like a challenge this is the right game for you.And remember if you find any bugs do lose something the mods can readily help you recover what was lost, the maximum that may be you need help developers to post their Log Files in the game forum.Forum where you can find several tips that will help you grow fast and strong.I await you in the game. o /If you like or dislike my opnion rate down here. \ /===================================Esse jogo te prende do inicio ao fim.Diferente da grande maioria dos jogos este não é "pay-to-win", existem métodos faceis de se conseguir todos os recursos.Existem alguns bugs e problemas que podem incomodar no inicio, mas o jogo conta com exelente grupo de mods prontos para ajudalo, no  chat do jogo. E em caso de nenhum estar presente, a grande maioria dos jogadores tende a ajudar os novatos.O jogo também conta com um sistema de PVP que permite apenas que tropas com poderes similares se enfrentem, fazendo assim com que nenhum veterano possa vir e esmagar você.Além de que você pode facilmente evitar todas as batalhas que não quiser enfrentar, apenas pagando pequenos valores de recursos.A cada batalha mesmo que você se renda, recebe proteção contra ataques que pode ser cancelada facilmente.O unico recurso importante do jogo "Crowns" pode ser ganho de varias formas (pvp, pve, coop) além de conversao de "gold" em "Crowns" e para os que tem dinheiro é possivel comprar.Também é possivel se unir em alianças, que permitem a construção de um "guild hall" que permite aumentar ainda mais sua capacidade de combate e obtençao de recursos ao aumentar a quantidade de exercitos que você pode pussuir.Varias unidades especiais como Dragões e Minotauros. Unidades de cura, unidades de cerco e muitas outras.Se você gosta de jogos como age of empires online e gostaria de um desafio este é o jogo certo para você.E lembre-se se encontrar qualquer bug que o faça perder algo os mods prontamente poderão ajuda-lo a recuperar o que foi perdido, o maximo que talvez você precisa seja ajudar os desenvolvedores ao postar os seus Log Files no forum do jogo.Forum onde podera encontrar varias dicas que te ajudarão a crescer rapido e forte.Aguardo vocês no jogo. o/Se gostou ou não da minha opnião avalie aqui embaixo. \/

												This game so full of bugs that i'm surprised bugs aren't flying out of my computer smacking me in the face. There nothing that isn't bugged in this game it has bugged quest that get so bad that it just breaks your whole town forcing you to delete it, and start a new. Like the first quet for the orc race which wants you to lore a orger into a spike trap after completeing it the spike trap suppose to disppaer, but it doesn't an everytime one of your workers or warriors walks over it it completely kills them everytime, and the orger respawn in your town killing you workers, and warriors everytime you reload your town. Then there pathfind bugs siege units get stuck on walls units get stuck climbing siege ladder or just stop moving for the reset of an instance if they some how survie a spike trap. Then Fire really annoying your troops will run into, and try to attack it for some reason, and even when it gone your unit still take damage when there in the area that was on fire. There some werid gather bug that just start in the most recent patch it took me 3 hours to collect 2 pieaces of wood when i had 10 workers try to cut wood. It should be 3-15 wood every sec depend on research or amount of workers. There also a bug with the ingame currency were you'll just randomly lose all of it for no reason so don't pay really cash on crowns cause you will lose them for no reason. Also you can gain crowns from PVP/PVE, but that also bugged 60% of the time your not reward with them after a match. An this is only about 1/5 of the bugs in the game there many more like treants bugged movement speed sometime they have a movement speed of 9999 they'll be so fast they just teleport across the battle field other time they have a movement speed of 2 they move so slow it takes them 3 hours to get across a map. There also a bug with the single player were it will say your cheating, and are unable to play the single player. The best bug so far is this extremely annoying bug that will just roll back your whole town to what it was when you started it when you get attack by another player, and the devs say this is a very rare which is Bull-**** cause it happen to about 15 people everyday which compared to the fact that 1000-1500 people login every day it about 1% of the population. So after 20 days 20% of the population town has been completely rolled back to the begining.  An the Devs are useless they don't fix bugs they take forever to post on the forums, hell there was one time were the devs didn't post anything on there website for 6 months striaght. People just started saying the game shutting down on there forums, and they didn't reply to any of thos post what they did do was delete thos post when they started posting on there site again. An for some reason the Devs are ban happy as it stands banning people for no reason at all. So overall don't waste your money on this game if you want to play it to see how buggy it is your self then just wait for it to go F2P/P2W.

But there are so many small things wrong with the game that the act of playing the game forces you into a battle with the game itself, you have to fight the bad game design to play this. and thats a real shame, i want to love it.

												I noticed that a lot of people are not recommending this game because of the feature, "Pay to win", is in the game but that is entirely optional. You don't have to pay. You only pay for the game with everything in it. Nothing forces you to pay. Not sure if that feature is still in the game though.Also I saw one review saying that you have to join the game by signing up on their website. That is not true although You have to register ingame and then receive an confirmation email for you to complete the registeration. This process do not take more than two minutes. You are required to do this in order to play the game online with friends and others. That's it.Anyway my review...Overall and ongoing, it is a fun game. I enjoy playing against AIs enemies as well as players whilst doing the storyline. I use the term, storyline, very loosely because it is almost very direct but you can do the quests whenever and in your own time. Yes, the game can and should have been better than what it is at the moment but I don't complain because it is a decent game.However it can be ugly due to cutscenes when you have conversations with some certain characters in the "storyline." The characters, by looking very closely, they look like they came from 90s games like Castle Strike or the old Warcraft series unless I forget to improve the graphics in the settings lol but that is manageable anyway because you don't look that closely often.Overall, I would say this is 7/10. Better than some games but could have been better.

												Well i may not have played for a long period of time in this game and it seems like i cannot login into the game now due to some bugs. I still think this is a good game overall, which is why even after i encounter a rare bug which still have had yet to be solved and the developers are working on it. The pros and cons are much like what other players have posted out in the reviews. I personally think the most attractive thing about kingdom wars are the pvp system and city protection shield. Unlike other games, this city protection shield only tickles when you are online on your kingdom and playing. When you go offline, your shield will be the same as when you login again. That is extremely attractive for players like me who are busy at work with little time to play games everyday. In other games, you will normally get sieged and lose resources or even the whole kingdom and you have to restart again which is very frustrating. Here, you can take things slowly as you want, explore the maps, conquer some npc cities or co-op siege with the community. If you have the time and army, you can just remove your shield and get onto some pvp for more fun.There are no worries on how you play and whether if there are overpowered players that pays to win as everyone is more or less the same depending on what strategy you use and time spent to experience the game. I hope everyone finds it fun to play too.

content:
31, 2015
												To be clear, the game is free; payment only gives you access to two one-use-only-ever chests of resources which you don't need one bit. There are also a couple DLCs, but if you look at development/patch notes you realise the vanilla game is rich and you won't want to pay for the stupid DLCs even into late game (e.g. there's a SP-only dlc - for the incompetent only). Please read on.3 races to choose from. Build your city, your army, your garrison, whatever labour forces you may want. Two very important factors that I find separate this game from those you may think this is similar to (involving MMO strategy games with building a settlement):1) You can't be attacked when offline. If you're not logged in and playing, you can't be attacked - meaning you don't need to worry or dedicate ANY time to this game. (You also have a cancellable 24hr-game-time-only battle protection for noobs, after which you'll have a great base. Additionally, battles are always between similar-strength forces).2) Your buildings can't be destroyed beyond 1% health. No conflict you will ever have will reset your city. Your buildings will be repaired over time and you'll just lose a token amount of resources, from what I understand you'll even get a few crowns (useful for upgrades or renaming units etc).I recommend, if you have any interest in a forgiving MMO RTS game with visual battles and really quite rich content, you should download and try a couple of the races. Read the descriptions to see what you'd be interested in and have a go. Just be wise on how you spend your crowns in the beginning as they're earned through quests (story line), battles, daily-gift of 1 crown if you login and trading in gold. P.S. you will want to make gold one of your primary mining operations, because if you shop around at some NPC towns/cities, you can usually buy more than 100 of any resource with 100 gold.I first tried the orcs (about 8 hrs), which I liked but I didn't do very well with.. Then I went to try the elves (now 14 hrs) and I love them. I don't get to design my city layout because we build in trees... but it's fun enough. Check out some of my woodelf screenshots.

content:
er 9, 2014
												Greetings steam comunity,5cents on why this game is recommendet by me and why you should waste a part of youre precious livetime playing it.First of all - why should one play it?- its fun- its free- its got castels- its got dragons (some of them slightly three headed)- its got mad magics- its not a pay2winTo give this a more serious aproach - the pro stuff:+ The game is a fine mixed castle building, army training and stuff wrecking experience(, a little of what i wanted as a stronghold fan :) ).+ Three playable races - elves, man and orcs.+ The gameplay of the battles is well done. Whyle the overal controling mechanism is rather simple one may invest some energy into the micromanagement of unit stances and rotations to gain the best from the troops efforts.+/- The castle is limited to a few number of designs and placement spots - which are nicely done to alow the player a rather wide range of tactical options.+ The Armys consist of up to 60 units, including sige engines and workers to get all those shiny coins from the corpses. As the units gain experience they may be upgradet to fit the players needs.+ The KI citys are chalanging and differ greatly in theyr designs+ The pvp system seems promising, presenting some late game challange, interesting battles and army compositions and the rather easy and fair mechanics of avoiding it by paying a part of ones ressources to the attacker.+ The overal unit ballancing seems to be sound and while its not perfect the developers are working to improve it.+ The comunity is alive and quite friendly.To play it is a little like....One may upgrade his camp to a formidable stronghold. While the walls rise high the troops may march to complete the first quests and plunder some stuff on the way. By doing so one aquires the in game currency of crowns - and even if there is a rather great heap of those in the in game store, the number one may get there is limited.In time the army will get experienced and gain enough power to take on the great citys of the world. The choice between looting a vanquished city or taking it on as a vassal is rather rewarding - more so if you just managed to gain a victory inside the walls of the capital :).On the dark side ther are a few things to be said:- The KI is just not up to the task. While the unit KI is ok with only some minor *whydoyoustupidhealersengagetheogersinmeeleagain >.<* kind of problems the KI troops on the battlefield remain stationary until engaged, most of the time. Most of the movements an enemy will do are rushing his remaining troops into the keep, if you break don its gate, and some counter charges if this gate did not belong to the keep. The odd exeption is a charge of the reinforcement troop. Those apear after half an hoer into a KI sige and are pathetically easy to block, by disengaging your troops from the city and mincing the reinforcements. - The ballancing of the fractions is not finished yet. The orc race seems to be a little on the downside, in the overal army performance.- There are few end game challanges out of pvp matches. If one has put some thought into the army composition and the upgrading of ones troops there will be next to nothing left to stop this army.-/+ The game is still in the making. While not essentialy bad, one may get slightly annoied by a few bugs and gliitches. Also ive experienced two mayor bugs up until now, of the *dude where is my castle?* kind. On the other hand: those where solved in a matter of one or two days and the mods did theyr best to recompensate the losses. Also one may hope to see some further improvements to the gameplay and some more content to come.oh, and cookies, because.... you know....In summa summarum i recommend this game.Hope to see you (try) torching my city some time :),best regards, Cyraion.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2015
												An excellent game overall, that will immerse most RTS players for at least a good few hours.Its fairly simple, with a very traditional setup of the three factions with strenghts and weaknesses. such as the Humans being the most durable overall, the Elves essentially having the strongest units but with greater weaknesses, and the Orcs being oddly enough the most frail but boasting the ability to quickly amass an army of considerable size at reduced cost.(Please note: This is more of a quick run-down of some of the features in the game, than an review. The idea is that you can more effectively decide if its features appeals to you, rather than read someone trash n praise it)Leveling up your units!:This game relies quite heavily on the concept of your troops not simply being something you purchase enough of, in the right combination but actually take into skirmishes to level up or train at friendly strongholds, to then tailor suit what stats you want to improve, such as more health, damage mitigation, health regeneration, stamina, and so on. Eventually you will pretty much max out all the stats but at that point you have spend quite a lot of gold on that unit, and considering its still very likely to get inconveniently killed while you look the other way you learn to pay special heed to keeping your investments alive and well protected. Special Units:Every faction has an array of faction specific units available to them, but theres also a common pool of special units available to all the factions. These units have roots in all three main factions, but theres also units from unplayable races, such as Dragons and Dwarves. These units almost always costs you Crowns, which is a measure of wealth and influence that you can spend on recruiting considerably attractive units to attack your enemies or defend your homeland.Quest line:Theres an rather involved lore in the game, and its often very nicely attached to the characters you interact with while playing the main quest line. As you go through the main quest of your faction your tasked with defending your homeland, your kingdom, and waging war against the two other factions in the game, and often also your own. Due to the somewhat sandbox-like nature of the game, the senarios you find yourself in is often rather interesting and gradually gives you useful rewards that greatly benefit the construction of your homeland, giving a smooth progression of your homeland, the story of the game, and your involvement in the game overall.Traits and RegionsIn the MMO portion of the game, after choosing a faction you will be asked to choose a region and two traits.These are important and should be chosen to match how you prefer to play the game. If your a "turtle" and enjoys defensive gameplay then naturally you may want to choose the most defensive region and traits, but if your more into siege and conquest than naturally you would do well to take a region that reflects that better.Either way, your choice of region and traits will play an immense factor in the performance of your strategies.Choose wisely. :)Non-Mandatory PvPIn the online MMO portion of the game you may be attacked by enemies at any time, but you need to actually accept the battle. Should you choose not to, or let the timer run out you will forfeit a small portion of your resources as a tribute to be left alone. Even if no resources are available fighting PvP is never mandatory. As you start out with a new homeland you will have 24 hours of real time protection against PvP attacks to get you started. Notice that this time is only ticking while your in-game. Additionally, every time you pay a tribute or conclude a PvP match you will be given a small PvP Protection time.It is also possible to purchase PvP protection for Crowns.The graphics, performance, and the gameplay itself have gradually improved over time, with updates coming out frequently enough for a game you only pay for once. (Not including the micro transaction-like boosts available in the market, and additional features) The gameplay in singleplayer, whether in the online MMO world or not, is very stable but once you have an actual fight not against the AI, but another player it soon becomes a bit of a mess.(This includes co-op aswell) Reasonably playable, yes, but still very annoying at times. However, they have worked hard to improve this game and the future update expected to come out this month, which will apperantly overhaul the entire thing onto a more stable engine will hopefully bring back much of the player base and thus hopefully bring some more life back into this, in all honesty, very awesome game.(If you wish to know more details about the game, i have found a wiki with more details for you)http://strategywiki.org/wiki/Dawn_of_FantasyYes, it does have some problems now and then but this game does deserve a chance if it calls out to you in general.Regards,Brandt.

												I've played for almost 7 hours and still don't have an army big enough to lay siege to another town, making for a boring experience. (The "Very Easy" opponent is still twice as strong as my army.) Starting out, resource-gathering is agonizingly slow. The UI is a mess; there are actually elements that overlap, and some elements aren't explained, so I don't even know what clicking on them does. Certain resources, like deers for elves, you can't count, or delete, but there is apparently a limit on how many you should create. The graphics are low quality, even on max settings. At times, it is difficult to actually see what I'm looking at.I've been an RTS gamer since the original AOE and SC. I've played Total War, Stronghold, C&C, Empire Earth, etc. I love the genre, and I love the concept that the developers are trying to implement with this game, but it's just very unenjoyable to play, even though I really wanted to like this game.

content:
23, 2015
												Kingwom Wars I still remember my thrill when I heard about this game being released. If I had to explain this game in one sentence it would be: The game is like Travian, Tribal Wars, ... but in real time 3D RTS mode.I have little play time on steam, that is because steam release was buggy at start, it payed off more to play using official launcher, meaning not using steam. The gameplay is simple, you start with a town which you upgrade. It has no deep depth of techology, it is rather simple and straight forward. You do not even need super strong economy to get decent army. I mostly play Elfs since I find their economy and troops most suitable to me (Archers :) ). Game has single player and multiplayer side which do no differ too much. You can play singleplayer offline with no problems, multiplayer gets you closer to other players. Multiplyer is same as singleplayer but you can go into CO-OP battles with other players, either with or against them. Maximum players inbattle are 2v2, which is kinda limiting. Guild/Clan/Alliance has meaning in terms helping each other during attacks. Game itself looks like Total wars series where troops and cities are managed on global map, while battle itself is in spirit of total war series where 2 armies clash. Combat system is same as with total war series archers(mounted, foot, crossbows), infantry(heavy knights, pikemen, swordsmen), cavalry (one type mounted knight, elfs have mounted archers), monsters with orcs etc. Each unit formation could lvl till 20 and had stat points for you to manually upgrade which provides decent ammount of depth. Each unit type has its special skills, where some have to be researched using crows, which are acquired with battles and quests. At start it was that simple, during time game developers kept close contact with comunity and invested great time to fixing bugs and providing new content. At release time game was once time purchase, now it is free to play model with premium. New content added mages, dragons, dwarfs, new heroes/special units, sieges but for all of it you need massive ammount of crowns which arent easy to get. There are also some bugs where you spend 250 crowns, but s*it happens, server reverses your upgrade and town state and u lose 250 crowns which finally made me quit game. Game itself is fun and worth playing, developers are moving forward and wont forsake the game, but KW2 is comming and you can feel that they are more focused on that release. Have fun it is nice game.

content:
er 7, 2014
												I played Dawn of Fantasy back in its early closed beta. It was...horrible. So many game breaking glitches, errors, units disappearing, the hero disappearing...just so many things. Luckily, the developpers are always on the prowl so they listened to everything we had to say...and they still do today. I've rarely seen developpers being so active, especially for such a lengthy amount of time.Now...I have yet to find a single bug. It took some time, but the game is in a great functioning state. There are a little jitters here and there, but they don't cause any real problems. This game has three races: Orks, Elves, and Humans. There is also the rumor of the possible coming undead race, but let's not get ahead of ourselves. (See...See what I did there? Ahead? You know...un...undea-Headless Horseman...)Unlike many other RTS games where the differences are just aesthetical or very minor, all three races are heavily different from eachother. Where humans use peasants to mine, chop wood, and kill livestock, elves need wood spirits to gather wood. And the other races do not have the same form of livestock as the humans. Elves have unicorns and Orks have a type of 'boar'. Both can be used in combat and, while the boar can be killed and have its meat taken, the unicorns give a steady trickle of gold (and can be used to protect your gatherers from wolves).When you create a new race, you have the option to choose from three different regions of that race's territories. The only thing that changes, I've noticed, is the landscape. This affects the placement of your soon-to-be walls and will create different kinds of tactics when attacking and defending players/npc towns. Afterwards, you have the option of choosing between different traits that will become permanent for that city, although the region you choose already possesses a few natural traits that will be added to your two choices. This makes some strategic decisions on developping your region change, as the traits affect ressource income, training, building, and stats of units. Units are also varied. Where humans have a good balance between unit types (melee, range, siege, cavalry), orks are more centered around melee, health, and anger issues, while elves are more centered around range and speed. I might be mistaking, but this is how I've percieved all three.Some units have abilities specific to them, such as human knights being able to heal nearby units or the elves ranged cavalry being able to use an arrow volley (accelerates their firing rates).For you, the player, you are represented by a 'hero' (that you can rename with crowns. More on those later). This hero allows you to interact with NPCs on the maps, allowing you to buy and sell ressources, buy mercenaries (this is the only way to get units from the other factions), or train your troops (including your hero). To travel on the world map, you need your hero to lead the army that you create. Depending on what units you bring with you, the amount of ressources you can carry with you increases. You can only carry a certain amount of wood, meat, and stone, so be cautious. As for your gold, you can carry however much you want! Except 'thieves' will start stealing the amount that exceeds your ressource cap. This also happens in your town.You have several options when travelling on the world map. You can set up a camp (with three defensive levels depending on the ressources that army possesses) which allows you to attack player cities. These camps can let you mine for ressources (if you have gatherers) and recruit units from your race to bolster your sieging force. You can also fight on the map, allowing you to see what is in the region. If you do it from a camp, you'll have a place to retreat to if you're overwhelmed. If you have no defences, well...This is a great way to see the regions without towns or cities. Sssilistra, for example...Nah. Why would I spoil that for you?You can also siege the npc towns on the map and conquer them, they become 'allied' with you. Plus, you get to loot the corpses on that map if you have gatherers and won. Hooray for corpse desecration! Otherwise, there's not much use with allying with npc towns apart from trading, but that only gives you a fickle amount of ressource income.Sieging can be slow, especially with the accuracy provided by your trebuchets/siege catapults/ bolt throwers, and with the many defenses that can be placed in a city or town, you best be wise on where you go to fight as you can be annihilated in just a few seconds. The fun part is when you enter the city after tearing down the walls and the defenses.Now, there's the matter of crowns and special units. Before you ask; No. The special units do not cause a pay-to-win situation. They can killed just as easily as any other unit...sometimes. It depends on the unit. First, let's talk about crowns. Crowns are the special currency bought with in-game money, but they can also be obtained in-game via combat and completing quests. These are used for research and constructing certain buildings. The demands for the buildings are minor and will certainly just take you a single trip on the world map and 'entering the region' to get the crowns needed. A few bandits and there you go. You got your building plus some extra. You might've gotten enough for the beginner's research too!Now, for the special units. Before the game became free to play, you just needed enough crowns to buy a dwarf unit or a dragon from the market. Now, you need not only the crowns, but the building as well, and these take a CRAZY amount of ressources to build! Not only that, but you have the crowns that are eaten up by the buildings. This prevents everyone from having too many of these units seeing how powerful they are. I find it both logical and crippling when thinking about the research needed to unlock the spells for the three mage types (provided you even manage to recruit one). You can no longer get tons of dragons or hydras as, to do so, you need to build several of the buildings dedicated to recruiting them seeing as only one beast cage can sustain one dragon or hydra. This is a good thing as, before the regulation of its power, a dragon could annihilate entire groups of units with a single fireball, not to mention the fire spreading in the town and destroying everything but the walls.Now, it's reasonably powerful, but cannot do anything on its own. It can't. Don't even try. I'm serious. Don't make it walk over there on its own. Because of these extreme limitations on the special units, you're still depending heavily on your regular units. Not only that, but player towns might harbor a dragon, so I would advise you to carry a dragon slayer, if you can get him out of the tavern.Another feature related to PVP is the protection time. You can buy this from the barracks for crowns. There's a large amount of different times, so don't worry. The timer does not keep going when you've logged out. It resumes when you continue playing in that town, however. Building and ressource gathering continues.As for the simpler things, I cannot percieve graphics the same as other people, so, for me, these are still pretty good. The music fits the time period this is set in and doesn't disappoint, although more variety would be needed.The game isn't perfect, but perfection leads to stagnation.

content:
er 26, 2014
												Let me tell you a thing or two;  How many games had you played, That is based on Real Time of stragegy?  How many games had you played, Like Starcraft 2, And you hates having to rebuild everything? How many games had you played, Where you just want to control your own soldiers into battle How many games had you played, Where there is no actual pay to win features? [Like path of exile!] Well, This is one of those game, And It's free.After years, Not alot of players get an opportunity of a decent gameplay where everything does not prevent them from trying to advance in the game. The best thing is currently about this game is;- The developers do interact with the players once the while, thus making the game much more enjoyable for the players- Instead of going the dull ol' fashioned where in Starcraft 2, You have to rebuild from ground one, You can skip that.- There are three races in the game; The human, The Elves and the orc. They have their own way of survivals, Learn it.-  Got dwarves. All race can have 'em. Dwarves. Dragons too.- There is no literal pay to win feature. Those who do think there is, is just thinking pessimistic. The reality is the Crown systems does not prevent pay to win, rather Crowns can be obtained via having vassal towns, Players Versues Players, completing quests, and clearing reigons of NPC. The crowns are essential to many mechanic of the game to unlock better equipments and building upgrades that will determine the player's activity in PvP and PvE. In addition that the only two things that are locked are Skrimishes and Single Player Campagin, but those two do not influence the direct gameplay of original. becuase Single player campagin will be the same as MMO-verisoned, The difference is no player versues players and does not requires internet connection. Skrimishes on other hand is a 'Testing Ground', Where you trains your tactic and you can use said tactics to your gameplay, but It won't influence the gameplay via units, resources or any means. rather just a training ground.- CO-OP Player versues Environment, Your best friend can help you take on Dagbor!The downsides, however. . . The Downsides only not so permanent and may be gone in next updates, and some downsides are from the player's gamestyle.- The game have bad server hosting, Meaning you can accidently lose connection or reception to the server. The worst to experience is a rollback, however you can solve it by validating the game via Steam, And If it does not solve, then you can go to game's file and go to the game's forum, then place down the Log 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 into the techinal support thread and state what happened to you.  - The players will alway use a wizard of the Deep. The Wizard of the deep is the wizard designed for player veruses players combat and will wreck most of your army. It's expensive immortal [Immortals unit cannot die, They will lose a few level, but they cannot be killed permanently.] unit that cost at most 120 crowns, excluding the cost to get the spells required. The Wizard of the deep can be a major turnoff for many players who are forced to face them in combat because It's designed to destroy majority of army before wizard get defeated.  - Lack of players also make community small. only 150 players strong per day, and sometime peaking 200, and lowest is 95. The community is not average toxic, and can be friendly at most time. Some players are willing to assist you in understanding the game mechanic, but most are usually quiet and/or the chatbox is not working for them. It's the common issue in the server host connection that Chatbox servers does not connect successfully to the other players sometime and breaks, Not allowing the players to communicate with the community.

content:
er 9, 2014
												Greetings steam comunity,5cents on why this game is recommendet by me and why you should waste a part of youre precious livetime playing it.First of all - why should one play it?- its fun- its free- its got castels- its got dragons (some of them slightly three headed)- its got mad magics- its not a pay2winTo give this a more serious aproach - the pro stuff:+ The game is a fine mixed castle building, army training and stuff wrecking experience(, a little of what i wanted as a stronghold fan :) ).+ Three playable races - elves, man and orcs.+ The gameplay of the battles is well done. Whyle the overal controling mechanism is rather simple one may invest some energy into the micromanagement of unit stances and rotations to gain the best from the troops efforts.+/- The castle is limited to a few number of designs and placement spots - which are nicely done to alow the player a rather wide range of tactical options.+ The Armys consist of up to 60 units, including sige engines and workers to get all those shiny coins from the corpses. As the units gain experience they may be upgradet to fit the players needs.+ The KI citys are chalanging and differ greatly in theyr designs+ The pvp system seems promising, presenting some late game challange, interesting battles and army compositions and the rather easy and fair mechanics of avoiding it by paying a part of ones ressources to the attacker.+ The overal unit ballancing seems to be sound and while its not perfect the developers are working to improve it.+ The comunity is alive and quite friendly.To play it is a little like....One may upgrade his camp to a formidable stronghold. While the walls rise high the troops may march to complete the first quests and plunder some stuff on the way. By doing so one aquires the in game currency of crowns - and even if there is a rather great heap of those in the in game store, the number one may get there is limited.In time the army will get experienced and gain enough power to take on the great citys of the world. The choice between looting a vanquished city or taking it on as a vassal is rather rewarding - more so if you just managed to gain a victory inside the walls of the capital :).On the dark side ther are a few things to be said:- The KI is just not up to the task. While the unit KI is ok with only some minor *whydoyoustupidhealersengagetheogersinmeeleagain >.<* kind of problems the KI troops on the battlefield remain stationary until engaged, most of the time. Most of the movements an enemy will do are rushing his remaining troops into the keep, if you break don its gate, and some counter charges if this gate did not belong to the keep. The odd exeption is a charge of the reinforcement troop. Those apear after half an hoer into a KI sige and are pathetically easy to block, by disengaging your troops from the city and mincing the reinforcements. - The ballancing of the fractions is not finished yet. The orc race seems to be a little on the downside, in the overal army performance.- There are few end game challanges out of pvp matches. If one has put some thought into the army composition and the upgrading of ones troops there will be next to nothing left to stop this army.-/+ The game is still in the making. While not essentialy bad, one may get slightly annoied by a few bugs and gliitches. Also ive experienced two mayor bugs up until now, of the *dude where is my castle?* kind. On the other hand: those where solved in a matter of one or two days and the mods did theyr best to recompensate the losses. Also one may hope to see some further improvements to the gameplay and some more content to come.oh, and cookies, because.... you know....In summa summarum i recommend this game.Hope to see you (try) torching my city some time :),best regards, Cyraion.

content:
8, 2015
												An excellent game overall, that will immerse most RTS players for at least a good few hours.Its fairly simple, with a very traditional setup of the three factions with strenghts and weaknesses. such as the Humans being the most durable overall, the Elves essentially having the strongest units but with greater weaknesses, and the Orcs being oddly enough the most frail but boasting the ability to quickly amass an army of considerable size at reduced cost.(Please note: This is more of a quick run-down of some of the features in the game, than an review. The idea is that you can more effectively decide if its features appeals to you, rather than read someone trash n praise it)Leveling up your units!:This game relies quite heavily on the concept of your troops not simply being something you purchase enough of, in the right combination but actually take into skirmishes to level up or train at friendly strongholds, to then tailor suit what stats you want to improve, such as more health, damage mitigation, health regeneration, stamina, and so on. Eventually you will pretty much max out all the stats but at that point you have spend quite a lot of gold on that unit, and considering its still very likely to get inconveniently killed while you look the other way you learn to pay special heed to keeping your investments alive and well protected. Special Units:Every faction has an array of faction specific units available to them, but theres also a common pool of special units available to all the factions. These units have roots in all three main factions, but theres also units from unplayable races, such as Dragons and Dwarves. These units almost always costs you Crowns, which is a measure of wealth and influence that you can spend on recruiting considerably attractive units to attack your enemies or defend your homeland.Quest line:Theres an rather involved lore in the game, and its often very nicely attached to the characters you interact with while playing the main quest line. As you go through the main quest of your faction your tasked with defending your homeland, your kingdom, and waging war against the two other factions in the game, and often also your own. Due to the somewhat sandbox-like nature of the game, the senarios you find yourself in is often rather interesting and gradually gives you useful rewards that greatly benefit the construction of your homeland, giving a smooth progression of your homeland, the story of the game, and your involvement in the game overall.Traits and RegionsIn the MMO portion of the game, after choosing a faction you will be asked to choose a region and two traits.These are important and should be chosen to match how you prefer to play the game. If your a "turtle" and enjoys defensive gameplay then naturally you may want to choose the most defensive region and traits, but if your more into siege and conquest than naturally you would do well to take a region that reflects that better.Either way, your choice of region and traits will play an immense factor in the performance of your strategies.Choose wisely. :)Non-Mandatory PvPIn the online MMO portion of the game you may be attacked by enemies at any time, but you need to actually accept the battle. Should you choose not to, or let the timer run out you will forfeit a small portion of your resources as a tribute to be left alone. Even if no resources are available fighting PvP is never mandatory. As you start out with a new homeland you will have 24 hours of real time protection against PvP attacks to get you started. Notice that this time is only ticking while your in-game. Additionally, every time you pay a tribute or conclude a PvP match you will be given a small PvP Protection time.It is also possible to purchase PvP protection for Crowns.The graphics, performance, and the gameplay itself have gradually improved over time, with updates coming out frequently enough for a game you only pay for once. (Not including the micro transaction-like boosts available in the market, and additional features) The gameplay in singleplayer, whether in the online MMO world or not, is very stable but once you have an actual fight not against the AI, but another player it soon becomes a bit of a mess.(This includes co-op aswell) Reasonably playable, yes, but still very annoying at times. However, they have worked hard to improve this game and the future update expected to come out this month, which will apperantly overhaul the entire thing onto a more stable engine will hopefully bring back much of the player base and thus hopefully bring some more life back into this, in all honesty, very awesome game.(If you wish to know more details about the game, i have found a wiki with more details for you)http://strategywiki.org/wiki/Dawn_of_FantasyYes, it does have some problems now and then but this game does deserve a chance if it calls out to you in general.Regards,Brandt.

content:
er 6, 2014
												Having played several "free to play" games, this one actually delivers on not needing to pay to win. The in-game currency called "crowns" is obtained through multiple ways from questing to pvp. With premium, gains are doubled but even without a player can amass wealth from sieges and quests in a matter of two or three hours. City management is simple and straightforward as resources are close at hand and placement of buildings is set by building plots scattered around the landscape. Time and crowns are all that is really needed to construct a powerful castle and the time goes by quickly as you fight to gain crowns. There are a diverse number of troops to choose from. Recruitment can include the troops of your own race as well as mercenaries when camping in foreign lands and dwarves and beasts from special buildings. Only three playable races are available: elves, orcs, and humans. Hopefully dwarves will be added in the future and possibly dragons (please). Battles and troop management are split between the world map and specific battlegrounds and are fairly easy to grasp. The only complaint towards troops in battle is their refusal to listen to certain orders. When you send cavalry in to feint an enemy into charging and the cavalry doesn't retreat when you tell them to, your strategy gets ruined and you are forced to en masse charge or risk losing part of your army. Aside from the troop command issue, the game is both fun and addicting as one could spend hours trying to earn crowns, conquer cities, and improve his/her own. Coupled with the game actually being fair and not requiring real money to be good, I would recommend it to any seeking a fun, free-to-play strategy game.
